287.text: One of the features, though, of disgust,

290.text: is not just its universality and its strength,

293.text: but the way that it works through association.

296.text: So when one disgusting thing touches a clean thing,

300.text: that clean thing becomes disgusting, not the other way around.

303.text: This makes it very useful as a strategy if you want to

306.text: convince somebody that an object or an individual

308.text: or an entire social group is disgusting and should be avoided.

312.text: The philosopher Martha Nussbaum points this out

316.text: properties -- sliminess, bad smell, stickiness, decay, foulness --

319.text: have been repeatedly and monotonously been associated with ...

322.text: Jews, women, homosexuals, untouchables, lower-class people --

326.text: all of those are imagined as tainted by the dirt of the body."

774.text: Okay. The fact that emotions influence our judgment

778.text: should come as no surprise. I mean,

780.text: that's part of how emotions work.

781.text: They not only motivate you to behave in certain ways,

783.text: but they change the way you think.

785.text: In the case of disgust, what is a little bit more surprising

787.text: is the scope of this influence. It makes perfect sense,

791.text: and it's a very good emotion for us to have, that disgust

794.text: would make me change the way that I perceive

796.text: the physical world whenever contamination is possible.

799.text: It makes less sense that an emotion that was built

802.text: to prevent me from ingesting poison should predict

805.text: who I'm going to vote for in the upcoming presidential election.

809.text: The question of whether disgust ought to influence

814.text: certainly has to be complex, and might depend on exactly

817.text: what judgments we're talking about, and as a scientist,

820.text: we have to conclude sometimes that the scientific method

822.text: is just ill-equipped to answer these sorts of questions.

825.text: But one thing that I am fairly certain about is,

827.text: at the very least, what we can do with this research is

830.text: point to what questions we ought to ask in the first place.
